Um, I think (I could be wrong, but I think it was in these NY Times pages) that ALL of the Senate are in the 1% of income, if not wealth. And a good number of the members of the House are also in the 1% of income. So, for whose interest are they looking out?

Seems that Ms. Warren and the student loans is a breath of fresh air if e'er there was one.

Huh. Half the problem, maybe, but much easier to fix. The rise of the 1% is largely a direct effect of U.S. tax policy, which has given preference to capital gains, made the income tax rates much less progressive than they were in the middle of last century, and radically reduced real business tax rates.

It seems obfuscatory to start by admitting the 1% is half the issue, even an "important half", then delve into the difficult issues of unions and manufacturing and free trade and labor arbitrage, and finally conclude that the problem is that "liberals and conservatives" don't understand each other.

The conclusion the writer makes *may* apply to the other verbage but it certainly doesn't apply to the issue of the 1%. I am pretty sure Congress understands that issue plainly but simply doesn't want to address rising inequality. Why? Because it would pain their donors and country club buddies and also because they can lean on decades of anti-tax (freedom!) rhetoric from well-funded "think tanks".

I agree with you to a point. Have you ever visited a community college admissions office around enrollment time? Have you ever talked to people desperately looking for a skill that will give them a middle class living? I have. They're everywhere. I've seen people from all walks of life lining up to take nursing classes praying they'll get accepted into a program. Most nursing programs have limited slots by the way.
This whole notion that there's a skill crisis in this country is bogus. I work on the weekends at a part-time job at a warehouse for an internet company that sells tons of cat food and books online (Why people buy cat food online is beyond me. If you're too lazy to pick it up at the grocery store, you're pathetic). I work with lots of teachers who are underpaid and young people that have solid skill sets but they can't find a job outside of retail. So they work at the slavish online retailer's warehouse that pays barely above minimum wage and offers no benefits, yet this company soaks up every dime it can possibly get from local and state taxpayers. Gotta love those tax credits for the job creators!
People need to be paid a fair wage for their labor. They need to be participants in this economy and not victims of it. It used to be that way. It used to be the harder you worked, the more you got. Now you just work hard and get a lousy pay check that may or may not cover the rent, and you can forget about making enough to save.

There are a number of errors in this op-ed based upon accepting popular conceptions rather than seeking truth. While statistically people without college educations earn less, there are many jobs that require skills, rather than degrees, that pay in the range of 60 to 200 thousand a year. The key is for people to find a foothold in an industry or business that offers a pathway up and then progress over a period of years. Also, many employers seeking specific skills and abilities will allow the substitution of experience for a four year degree. The idea that those without college should consign themselves to a lifetime of poor pay is just wrong.

Consider, also, this: we have become biased in favor of those with degrees. This enables employers to set a minimum standard of a four year degree simply based on the assumption that someone without one might be of lower intelligence and can't stick to a task consistently enough to get a degree.

Employers in turn use the "no degree" excuse to reduce pay for those doing similar or the same work, so the lack of a degree statistically shows up as a lagging indicator of pay simply because of this discrimination. Employers leverage their power against employees.

The best way to attack income inequality is to pay people more for the value they bring, degreed or not. Unions are one way. Mass public insistence on greater fairness on pay scales is another. NOTHING happens in the world without workers at all levels.

Harriet, thanks for mentioning "trickle up." Trickle Up works, Trickle down, Nope.

Focusing on inequality is a mistake -- the focus should be on poverty (ameliorating it) and on mobility (ensuring it exists). If those problems are being handled as well as we can, then being concerned about inequality is simply venal jealousy wrapped up in holier than thou language. If we can reach a point where the lower class isn't suffering in poverty, and if the middle class has a strong and improving standard of living, then we're in good shape, whether or not there exists some 1% that is richer than they  need to be.

I think most of us don't agree that there's a line regarding "public privacy." If "most" did, there would not be so many overreaching surveillance technologies, both publicly and privately owned, allowed to follow us about our day.

As with so many social contradictions, I find it disingenuous for outrage to follow public photography, whether surreptitious Google Glass snapshots, or overt and obvious traditional cameras. The fear of being made fun of, and less likely of being "found out," should not trump artistic expression nor the advancement of personal technologies. That's regarding the civility of it.

Without regard for civility, cameras will proliferate as our gadgets learn to see for other reasons, and as companies continue to sell their wares, and as the demand for cheap "spy cameras" continues for those who feel the need to invade the privacy of others. There are enough laws we can't enforce against criminal behavior, and civil suits are prohibitively expensive. For the sake of personal sanity, try to get past the notion of being caught in an unflattering photo that may or may not be shared far and wide, and consider that the likelihood of anyone taking note, or having an attention span of more than a minute, or even being gratified in some way by the image of some unwitting stranger for more than the briefest moment is small. Few of us are so special as to be the focus of another's camera, and even when we are, we'll quickly be overwritten.

"salaries are fixed by the home institutions – you can’t write a grant to pay yourself double what you got last year for instance. Many scientists get by without submitting grants at all (those with so-called ‘hard money’ positions – like university lecturers or government researchers), and if they do, it is often to support other people. For each person being supported by a grant, you have to budget for their salary, fringe benefits and the mysterious ‘overhead’ (some 30 to 60% of the total) that gets taken by the institution. Once you add in some travel and facilities money, most standard individual PI grants end up in the neighbourhood of $100-200K per year, and so for a 3 year grant, something around $300-600K. For fieldwork in Greenland for instance or for outfitting a new lab, the numbers can be substantially higher. This might sound like a lot of money, but the PIs never see this as a lump sum (it is a grant to their institution, not them personally), and as noted above, most of it disappears into the system (to fund necessary things of course) before it gets anywhere near the researcher."

The issue of fairness is central to the solution of the problem of income in our country. It is not pointless. Subjective it may be, but the subjective views of the majority count in a democracy. Just because a view is subjective does not make it wrong or pointless.

Furthermore, the author's views are not wholly subjective--they are indeed supported by facts. Several undeniable objective facts:

1. Unions are weaker today then in the past.
2. Income equality exists between the highly educated and the less educated.
3. The way income is distributed in this country "unfair". By any definition--you choose, or let your neighbor choose, what unfair means, but this unfairness is a fact.

Reviving unions may not be the answer. I personally believe giving everybody college educations is not the answer. Finding a way to preserve dignity within an uneducated life would be good. Having the haves of the country feel a responsibility to the have-nots of the country would be good. Changing our priorities as a nation will be absolutely necessary. What makes us proud to be an American should not be viewed within the context of our strength and wealth but rather our caring and goodness of our lives. We can't be proud when so many of us are so poor or working so hard or are so worried as to make the pursuit of happiness a moot point.

Allow me to define basic fairness as compensation for all persons engaged in social endeavor sufficient to provide housing, sustenance, clothing, and time and opportunity for recreation. That would certainly be setting a low bar to clear for a basic human existence. In fact we need to provide that basic existence to reduce the recourse to criminality that is the only option for many of the numerous souls who are destitute. Maybe you call that a subjective difference, but I call it a real difference.

In fact, we (the federal government} can keep borrowing for a long time, and will do so; our debt is nothing as a problem compared to our masses of idle, impoverished, and dependent workers, and if you had ever bothered to read a decent economic commentary, readily available right here in the NY Times, you might understand that.

Fair taxation, and even more, a fair deal in the first place, would solve every problem that you mentioned; a reasonable and responsible war budget would also go far to reducing our continuing budget deficits, so long as those lost war jobs were replaced with public improvements actually representing an investment, and consequently, turning a profit.

@pwaldner

I'm not suggesting that fairness is pointless because it is subjective. They're two separate points. Fairness is subjective. Is it it unfair that a top hedge fund manager pays $150 million per year in federal taxes while a person in the lower 50% pays nothing in federal taxes. Or is it unfair that a top hedge fund manager has so much in disposable income and a person in the lower 50% has none? Depends upon your perspective.

Fairness is pointless because, as a political argument, it doesn't work. The argument has been made repeatedly since the Reagan cuts, and the gap has widened ever since.

Fairness is pointless because it obscures the hard and important questions of how much money to spend on the various programs and how to raise that money. The fairness issue is a cheap gimmick by politicians of both parties.

As for income equality existing between the highly educated and the less educated, that is true and undeniable. But what is also true and undeniable is that income inequality is far greater between the doctors and lawyers who are in the bottom top 1% and the hedge fund managers who are in the upper top 1%. All are highly educated, yet the gap is far greater than that between a doctor and a Walmart cashier.

Enough of this nonsense about the top 1%. Two points.

(1) The gap between the bottom top 1% and the upper top 1% ($367K vs. $1B+) is one thousand times greater than the gap between the bottom top 1% and top 10% ($367K vs. $111K). Moreover, hedge market managers making that $1B+ pay taxes at the carried interest rate (15%), not the top tax bracket (39.6%).

(2) The issue of fairness is wholly subjective and pointless. The real issues that matter are how and where we get the money to fully fund Medicare, Social Security, Defense, and interest on the national debt, as well as the remaining 25% of the budget; and how much longer we can keep on borrowing.
